quoteFirst: He said to me in the same manner that he had arrived at the Tuileries with his workmen and materials at six o'clock in the morning; that everything was so well constructed and put up that the King had not heard a sound; that his chief valet de chambre, having left the room for some commission
quoteTime: about seven o'clock in the morning
quoteLast: , had been much astonished upon seeing this apparatus; that the Marechal de Villeroy had only heard of it through him, and that the seats had been erected with such little noise that nobody had heard anything.  After having well examined everything with my eyes I advanced to the throne, then being finished; wishing to enter the second ante-chamber, some servants came to me, saying that I could not go in, all being locked up.
title: Memoirs of Louis XIV and His Court and of the Regency — Volume 12
author: Saint-Simon, Louis de Rouvroy, duc de, 1675-1755

quoteFirst: "On Wednesday last, the 5th day of August, 1863, I sighted the bark _Sea-Bride_,

quoteFirst: At certain hours of the day, the excitability is at its maximum; at a different period it practically disappears. The period of insensibility is

quoteFirst: [Meals.] The Filipino eats three times a day--
quoteLast: , 12, and at 7 or 8 in the evening. Those engaged in severe labor consume at each meal a chupa of rice; the common people, half a chupa at breakfast, one at mid-day, and half again in the evening, altogether two chupas.

quoteFirst: "The attack was renewed by the enemy
quoteTime: about seven o'clock in the morning
quoteLast: , and was bravely resisted by the limited number of troops I could bring into action until eleven o'clock, when orders were given for the army to establish itself on the new line. This it did in good order. The position I abandoned was one that I had held at a disadvantage; and I kept the troops on it as long as I did, only for the purpose of enabling me to hear of the approach of the force under Gen. Sedgwick.
title: The Campaign of Chancellorsville
author: Dodge, Theodore Ayrault, 1842-1909

quoteLast: , was let Blood about eleven the same day in her Foot; the first Blood was receiv'd in a Porringer, and within a little while it turn'd very white; the last Blood was received in a Sawcer, which turn'd white immediately, like the white of a Custard.

quoteFirst: I know a woman who has not missed her menses in twenty years; during those twenty years the menses have started every fourth Friday, almost always at the same hour. I know another one who has her menses every fourth Wednesday,
quoteLast: . She skipped her periods during her two pregnancies, then they were irregular for a while, then they came back to Wednesday. Other women have their menses on a certain day of the month, say the first or the fifth, regardless of the number of days in the month (such cases are, however, exceptional).
title:
Woman
Her Sex and Love Life
author: Robinson, William J. (William Josephus), 1867-1936

quoteFirst: He paid from four to seven francs a week for his lodgings, and lived in other respects accordingly. Potatoes and onions “were the chief of his diet.” He left his room regularly
quoteLast: , returned about the same hour at night, and went out very little evenings even to the group meetings, preferring to stay at home and read till a late hour. In fact, the only things his associates found to reproach him for were his over-seriousness and his taciturnity.
